Posts.Content: A Dec 19, 2005 press release by the U.S. Government National Institute for Environmental Health Sciences, states: “…nighttime exposure to artificial light stimulated the growth of human breast tumors by suppressing the levels of a key hormone called melatonin. The study also showed that extended periods of nighttime darkness greatly slowed the growth of these tumors”. Exposing your eyes to light at nighttime stops your pineal gland from making melatonin. Melatonin is a powerful cancer fighter. Ordinary white light contains a blue component. It is only this blue component that suppresses melatonin. Wearing blue blocking glasses two hours before going to bed can effectively increase nightime darkness, while allowing you to read, watch television, work on a computer, etc. The web site --- Message edited by CancerCompass staff: for personal protection, email address removed. Please review CancerCompass Member Guidelines at http://www.cancercompass.com/common/guidelines.html ----has further details.
Posts.Title: a Possible Way to Reduce One's Risk.
